about.title: About Aggrow
about.description1: Aggrow is an innovative agricultural technology platform designed to help farmers optimize their crop yields through data-driven insights and AI-powered recommendations.
about.description2: Our mission is to empower farmers with cutting-edge technology that simplifies decision-making, reduces resource wastage, and maximizes productivity while promoting sustainable farming practices.
about.description3: Founded by a team of agricultural experts and technology enthusiasts, Aggrow combines traditional farming wisdom with modern machine learning algorithms to provide practical solutions to everyday farming challenges.

diseaseDetection.title: Disease Detection
diseaseDetection.description: Identify plant diseases early through image recognition technology. Simply upload a photo of your affected plant, and our AI will diagnose the issue and suggest treatment options.

cropRecommendation.title: Crop Recommendation
cropRecommendation.description: Get personalized crop suggestions based on your soil composition, local climate data, and market trends to maximize your yield and profitability.

fertilizerRecommendation.title: Fertilizer Recommendation
fertilizerRecommendation.description: Receive tailored fertilizer recommendations based on soil tests and crop requirements to ensure optimal plant nutrition while minimizing environmental impact.

cropRecommendation.title: Crop Recommendation
cropRecommendation.subtitle: Enter the soil and climate details to get a recommended crop.

result.1: Reduce nitrogen inputs by avoiding nitrogen-rich fertilizers like composted manure, blood meal, urea, or ammonium nitrate.
result.2: Add carbon-rich materials such as straw, sawdust, or wood chips to balance excess nitrogen.
result.3: Plant nitrogen-scavenging crops like grasses or cereals to absorb excess nitrogen from the soil.
result.4: Leach excess nitrogen by applying moderate irrigation to wash away soluble nitrogen compounds.
result.5: Apply nitrification inhibitors to slow down the conversion of ammonium to nitrate, reducing nitrogen losses.

result.1: Add nitrogen-rich organic fertilizers such as composted manure, blood meal, or fish emulsion.
result.2: Apply nitrogen-rich inorganic fertilizers like urea (46% N) or ammonium sulfate (21% N).
result.3: Grow legumes like beans, peas, or clover to fix atmospheric nitrogen into the soil.
result.4: Use green manure by growing and tilling nitrogen-fixing cover crops like alfalfa or clover.
result.5: Apply well-decomposed compost to slowly release nitrogen and improve soil structure.
result.6: Use slow-release nitrogen fertilizers like sulfur-coated urea to provide a steady supply of nitrogen.
result.7: Apply split doses of nitrogen fertilizers (e.g., urea) during the growing season to maximize uptake.

result.1: Avoid phosphorus-rich fertilizers like bone meal, rock phosphate, DAP, or TSP to prevent excess phosphorus.
result.2: Add compost or microbial inoculants to enhance phosphorus absorption by plants.
result.3: Grow phosphorus-absorbing crops like sunflowers or grains to reduce excess phosphorus in the soil.
result.4: Optimize phosphorus availability by adjusting soil pH to 6.5â€“7 (add lime for acidic soil or sulfur for alkaline soil).
result.5: Apply phosphorus-solubilizing bacteria to improve plant phosphorus uptake and reduce excess phosphorus.
result.6: Use moderate irrigation to leach soluble phosphorus compounds.

result.1: Add phosphorus-rich organic fertilizers such as bone meal, rock phosphate, or fish bone meal.
result.2: Apply phosphorus-rich inorganic fertilizers like DAP (18:46:0) or TSP (0:46:0).
result.3: Apply compost with balanced nutrient content to provide a slow release of phosphorus.
result.4: Use mycorrhizal fungi by inoculating the soil with fungi that enhance phosphorus uptake by plant roots.
result.5: Adjust soil pH to 6â€“7 by adding lime (if acidic) or sulfur (if alkaline) to improve phosphorus availability.
result.6: Use water-soluble phosphorus fertilizers like monoammonium phosphate (MAP, 11:52:0) for quick availability.
result.7: Apply phosphorus fertilizers in bands near the root zone to improve uptake efficiency.

result.1: Avoid potassium fertilizers like wood ash, kelp meal, MOP, or SOP to prevent excess potassium buildup.
result.2: Leach excess potassium by applying moderate irrigation to wash away soluble potassium compounds.
result.3: Plant potassium-absorbing crops like potatoes or tomatoes to reduce excess potassium in the soil.
result.4: Add calcium or magnesium by applying gypsum or Epsom salt to balance excess potassium levels.

result.1: Add potassium-rich organic fertilizers such as wood ash, kelp meal, or greensand.
result.2: Apply potassium-rich inorganic fertilizers like muriate of potash (MOP, 0:0:60) or sulfate of potash (SOP, 0:0:50).
result.3: Apply compost with balanced nutrient content to provide a slow release of potassium.
result.4: Use cover crops like buckwheat or alfalfa to accumulate potassium in the soil.
result.5: Adjust soil pH to 6â€“7 by adding lime (if acidic) or sulfur (if alkaline) to improve potassium availability.
result.6: Use water-soluble potassium fertilizers like potassium nitrate (13:0:45) for quick availability.
result.7: Apply potassium fertilizers in split doses during the growing season to maximize uptake.

result.1: Add acidifying organic materials like pine needles, peat moss, or composted oak leaves to lower soil pH.
result.2: Apply acidifying inorganic materials like elemental sulfur or aluminum sulfate to lower soil pH.
result.3: Use acid-forming fertilizers like ammonium sulfate (21% N) to gradually reduce soil pH.
result.4: Leach excess alkalinity by applying moderate irrigation to wash away soluble salts.
result.5: Plant alkaline-tolerant crops like asparagus, cabbage, or spinach to thrive in high-pH soils.

result.1: Add agricultural lime or dolomite lime at a rate of 5â€“10 kg per 100 sq ft to raise soil pH.
result.2: Apply alkaline-forming fertilizers like calcium nitrate (15.5% N) to gradually increase soil pH.
result.3: Apply wood ash sparingly (1â€“2 kg per 100 sq ft) to increase soil pH and provide potassium.
result.4: Use alkaline organic fertilizers like composted manure or bone meal to raise soil pH gradually.
result.5: Plant acid-tolerant crops like blueberries, potatoes, or strawberries to thrive in low-pH soils.
